title: Students
text:
Tuition and Aid
I was an undergraduate in 2022 when the “largest tuition hike in 14 years” was met with upset, frustration, and despair. However, this graph reveals what is essentially a linear increase in tuition. Of course, a 4% increase of an increasing significant amount of money hits students harder each year, but this graph shows maintainance of the status quo.


Code
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(tidyverse)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(stringr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(tidyr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(ggplot2)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(dplyr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(ggthemes)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(hrbrthemes)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(plotly)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(scales)))

# Read the data
stu_aid <- read_csv("Stu.Aid.02.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

# Clean and convert data
stu_aid <- stu_aid %>%
  mutate(
    Year = as.integer(Year),
    `Average Aid` = as.numeric(`Average Aid`),
    `Percent Given Aid` = as.numeric(`Percent Given Aid`),
    `Total Tuition` = as.numeric(Total),
    Percent_Scaled = `Percent Given Aid` * 900  # Scaling the percent for visibility
  )

# Reshape the data into a long format
long_data <- stu_aid %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c("Average Aid", "Total Tuition", "Percent_Scaled"),
               names_to = "Metric",
               values_to = "Value") %>%
  mutate(Metric = case_when(
    Metric == "Average Aid" ~ "Average Aid",
    Metric == "Total Tuition" ~ "Total Tuition",
    Metric == "Percent_Scaled" ~ "Percent Given Aid"
  ))

# Create the ggplot with tooltips for the data
p <- ggplot(long_data, aes(x = Year, y = Value, color = Metric, group = Metric,
                           text = paste("Year:", Year,
                                        "<br>Value:", 
                                        ifelse(Metric == "Percent Given Aid", 
                                               scales::percent(Value / 900, scale = 1),  # Dividing back for percent display
                                               scales::label_dollar()(Value))))) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Student Aid Overview (2002–2023)",
       subtitle = "Solid lines: Aid & Tuition | Dashed line: % Receiving Aid",
       x = "Year", y = "Amount in Dollars",
       color = "Metric") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c(
    "Average Aid" = "#006400",           # Deep Emerald
    "Total Tuition" = "#002366",         # Deep Sapphire
    "Percent Given Aid" = "#c9b1c9"      # Deep Amethyst
  )) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_dollar(prefix = "$", big.mark = ","))

# Convert to Plotly for interactivity
interactive_plot <- ggplotly(p, tooltip = "text")

# Display the interactive plot
interactive_plot






Additionally, the university expanded their financial aid program to meet all demonstrated need for first-year domestic students in the fall of 2020. Interestingly, there is limited change in the percent of students given aid and the average aid amount. The average aid number represents “federal, state, local or institutional grant aid awarded to full-time first-time undergraduates,” so while full-demonstrated need is an excellent guarantee for students, it appears this was not a financial investment on the university and on average students did not benefit.

title: Limitations
text:
This project is limited by the data available. There is both too much data to sift through and, at the same time, not enough. The project relied on IPEDS data, which is a robust collection of information, but not without its shortcomings. The main issue I encountered with this dataset is the lack of consistent longitudinal data collection. Many key categories—such as faculty gender—changed their methods of collection and categorization at a certain point, making it difficult to trace trends across those methodological shifts. Additionally, some information I hoped would go back further in time—like tuition data—simply did not. Historically, data becomes more sparse and more difficult to find the further back you go, especially when focusing on a specific topic or institution.
I’m an amateur when it comes to data visualization. I took a few courses a couple of years ago, but I don’t have experience working with large datasets or advanced visualization methods beyond the beginner-friendly “ggplot2” library. I also acknowledge my own bias in this project: shaped by preconceived notions about the university and the “propaganda” I’ve encountered as both a BU student and staff member. BU presents its most positive sides to the public and student body, while inconvenient facts are often hidden away. This makes research even more challenging, as the narrative is primarily controlled by those who want the university to look good. Stories are told by university spokespeople. Achievements and milestones are filtered through official publications. History is curated on university websites and in university-authored books. The only thing that cannot lie—and cannot hide—is the data.

title: AP601 Capstone
text:
Amelia Layne

From Numbers to Narrative: A Data-Driven Portrait of Boston University
A brief institutional history of a single college, university, foundation, or association of your choosing
AP 601 History of Higher Education
21 April, 2025
Boston University

title: Faculty Analysis
text:
Data on faculty were obtained from the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System. This section focuses on gender and racial demographics in tenured and tenure-track faculty by rank in terms of number, and salary averages based on gender.

Gender Demographics
Before 1980, there were 34,390 female PhD recipients in the US compared to 144,208 male PhD recipients. The pool of women eligible to become full professors was limited, and given the amount of time and expertise needed to successfully proceed through the tenure and promotion process, it follows that there would be a smaller population of female tenured faculty members at the university.


Code
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(stringr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(tidyr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(ggplot2)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(dplyr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(ggthemes)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(hrbrthemes)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(plotly)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(scales)))


faculty_data <- read.csv("F.Sal.80.csv")

colnames_cleaned <- colnames(faculty_data)

colnames_cleaned <- str_replace_all(colnames_cleaned,
                "^Number\\.of\\.full\\.time\\.instructional\\.(faculty|staff)\\.(men|women|total)\\.\\.SAL(\\d{4})_.*\\.(Professor|Associate\\.professor|Assistant\\.professor).*",
                "Number_\\3_\\4_\\2") 
colnames_cleaned <- str_replace_all(colnames_cleaned,
                "^Average\\.salary\\.of\\.full\\.time\\.instructional\\.(faculty|staff)\\.(men|women|total)\\.\\.SAL(\\d{4})_.*\\.(Professor|Associate\\.professor|Assistant\\.professor).*",
                "Average_\\3_\\4_\\2") 


colnames(faculty_data) <- colnames_cleaned


long_data <- faculty_data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("Average"), 
               names_to = c("year", "rank", "gender"),
               names_pattern = "Average_(\\d{4})_(.*)_(.*)", 
               values_to = "salary") %>%
  mutate(year = as.integer(year))





long_count <- faculty_data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("Number"), 
               names_to = c("year", "rank", "gender"),
               names_pattern = "Number_(\\d{4})_(.*)_(.*)", 
               values_to = "n") %>%
  mutate(year = as.integer(year))


long_combined <- left_join(long_data, long_count, by = c("year", "rank", "gender"))


gender_count_data <- long_combined %>%
  filter(gender %in% c("women", "men")) %>%
  select(year, rank, gender, n)

gender_count_plot <- ggplot(gender_count_data, aes(x = year, y = n, color = gender, group = gender,
                                                   text = paste("Year:", year,
                                                                "<br>Count:", n))) +
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~rank) +
  labs(title = "Number of Faculty by Gender from 1980-2011", x = "Year", y = "Faculty Count") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("women" = "#993366", "men" = "#5d437c")) +
  theme_few()


interactive_gender_plot <- ggplotly(gender_count_plot, tooltip = "text")

interactive_gender_plot






However, in 1979, the number of PhDs awarded per year would reach 95,631, soon to hit six digits from which it would never again decrease. Steadily and consistently, the percentage of female PhD recipients would increase from 29.0% in 1980 to then exceed 50% in 2006. Women are predicted to be the majority of PhD recipients in projections.
Yet, the “leaky pipeline” phenomenon is evident here. Women are remaining as junior faculty and the tenured faculty positions remain predominantly male. We can see a push to hire women at the assistant professor level beginning in around 2015. Yet, the tenure process is typically 6-7 years, so we would expect to see that the number of female associate professors begins to increase in around 2020. Evidently, women are not achieving tenure, despite nearly a double in the number of assistant professors who are women.


Code
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(stringr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)
library(plotly)
library(ggthemes)


faculty_curr <- read.csv("F.Num.Curr.csv")



colnames(faculty_curr) <- str_replace_all(colnames(faculty_curr), "_RV", "")

colnames_cleaned <- colnames(faculty_curr)

colnames_cleaned <- str_replace_all(colnames(faculty_curr), "\\.{1,}", "_") 

colnames_cleaned <- str_replace_all(colnames_cleaned, "^_|_$", "")

colnames(faculty_curr) <- colnames_cleaned

colnames_cleaned <- str_replace_all(colnames_cleaned,
                                    "(S)(\\d{4})_IS_Full_time_instructional_professors",
                                    "\\2_Professor")

colnames_cleaned <- str_replace_all(colnames_cleaned,
                                    "(total|men|women)_(Grand|American_Indian_or_Alaska_Native|Asian|Black|Hispanic|NHPI|White|Two|Unknown)",
                                    "\\2_\\3_\\1")




# Ensure it's in the desired format
colnames_cleaned <- str_replace_all(colnames_cleaned,
                                    "(S)(\\d{4})",
                                    "\\2")
# Replace race/ethnicity terms with abbreviations, including Two and Unknown
colnames_cleaned <- str_replace_all(colnames_cleaned,
                                    c("American_Indian_or_Alaska_Native" = "AIAN",
                                      "Black_or_African_American" = "Black",
                                      "White" = "White",
                                      "Asian" = "Asian",
                                      "Hispanic_or_Latino" = "Hispanic",
                                      "Native_Hawaiian_or_Other_Pacific_Islander" = "NHPI",
                                      "Two_or_more_races" = "Two",
                                      "Race_ethnicity_unknown" = "Unknown"))

colnames_cleaned <- colnames(faculty_curr) %>%
  # Simplify rank
  str_replace_all("Full_time_instructional_professors", "Professor") %>%
  str_replace_all("Full_time_instructional_associate_professors", "Associate") %>%
  str_replace_all("Full_time_instructional_assistant_professors", "Assistant") %>%
  str_replace("_S(\\d{4})_IS_", "_\\1_") %>%
  str_replace_all("American_Indian_or_Alaska_Native", "AIAN") %>%
  str_replace_all("Black_or_African_American", "Black") %>%
  str_replace_all("Hispanic_or_Latino", "Hispanic") %>%
  str_replace_all("Asian", "Asian") %>%
  str_replace_all("Native_Hawaiian_or_Other_Pacific_Islander", "NHPI") %>%
  str_replace_all("White", "White") %>%
  str_replace_all("Two_or_more_races", "Two") %>%
  str_replace_all("Race_ethnicity_unknown", "Unknown") %>%
  str_replace_all("Grand_total", "Grand")


colnames(faculty_curr) <- colnames_cleaned



long_faculty <- faculty_curr %>%
  pivot_longer(
    -instnm,
    names_to = "key",
    values_to = "n"
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    gender = case_when(
      str_detect(key, "_men_") ~ "men",
      str_detect(key, "_women_") ~ "women",
      str_detect(key, "_total_") ~ "total",
      str_detect(key, "_Grand_men_") ~ "men",
      str_detect(key, "_Grand_women_") ~ "women",
      str_detect(key, "^Grand_\\d{4}_") ~ "total",
      TRUE ~ NA_character_
    ),
    year = str_extract(key, "\\d{4}"),
    rank = case_when(
      str_detect(key, "Professor$") ~ "Professor",
      str_detect(key, "Associate$") ~ "Associate",
      str_detect(key, "Assistant$") ~ "Assistant",
      TRUE ~ "Unknown"
    ),
    race = case_when(
      str_detect(key, "^Grand") ~ "grand",
      str_detect(key, "^AIAN") ~ "AIAN",
      str_detect(key, "^Black") ~ "Black",
      str_detect(key, "^White") ~ "White",
      str_detect(key, "^Asian") ~ "Asian",
      str_detect(key, "^Hispanic") ~ "Hispanic",
      str_detect(key, "^NHPI") ~ "NHPI",
      str_detect(key, "^Two") ~ "Two",
      str_detect(key, "^Unknown") ~ "Unknown",
      TRUE ~ NA_character_
    )
  ) %>%
  filter(race == "grand") %>%
  select(instnm, year, rank, gender, n)




gender_count_plot <- ggplot(long_faculty %>% filter(gender %in% c("men", "women")),
                            aes(x = year, y = n, color = gender, group = gender,
                                text = paste("Year:", year,
                                             "<br>Count:", n))) +
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~rank) +
  labs(title = "Number of Faculty by Gender from 2012-2023",
       x = "Year", y = "Faculty Count") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("women" = "#993366", "men" = "#5d437c")) +
  theme_few()+ scale_x_discrete(breaks = function(x) x[seq(1, length(x), by = 2)]) + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))



interactive_gender_plot <- ggplotly(gender_count_plot, tooltip = "text")
interactive_gender_plot






The increase in 2015 cannot be explained by a singular event or law. However, at Boston University in that moment, there were internal and external forces at play. President Robert A. Brown entered his tenth year as the tenth president of the university with a robust new Strategic Plan in place.
The 2015 strategic plan aimed to transform the university into a world-class research institution, and the items all included faculty improvement goals.
This includes

Big Thinking Meets Big Reality
“We had to figure out what would really make a difference to the University, to the students, to the world. Then break it down into realistic actions. Like hiring more professors—amazing people who inspire amazing people.”
Footing the Bill
“We’re halfway through the timeline of our first-ever, $1B comprehensive fundraising effort, and… we’re closer to our goal than we expected: over $800M to date. Among other things, these funds are… attracting and retaining world-class faculty.”
Chartering Success
“There are a lot of ways to describe our progress… There’s our hiring and mentoring of the next generation of award-winning professors and researchers.
Being Better than Just Great
“Aside from making it easier for our undergraduates to move between colleges, and bringing more diversity on both sides of the lectern, we’re committed to ongoing, rigorous academic reviews of all our offerings, focusing on the quality of our educational programs, faculty, and research.”
Mapping our Progress
“We created 94 new faculty positions and dropped our student/faculty ratio from 15:1 to 12.5:1”

BU also was invited to join the prestigious Association of American Universities in 2012, which likely made the university hold itself to higher standards in order to continue to be mentioned in the save breath as institutions such as Harvard, Brown, Stanford, Johns Hopkins, MIT, and the like


Salary Discrepancies

  filter(gender != "total")



p_salary <- ggplot(filtered_data, aes(x = year, y = salary, color = gender, group = gender,
                                      text = paste("Year:", year,
                                                   "<br>Salary:", scales::label_dollar()(salary),

interactive_salary_plot <- ggplotly(p_salary, tooltip = "text")

interactive_salary_plot








Code
library(tidyverse)
library(stringr)
library(ggthemes)
library(scales)
library(plotly)

faculty_data <- read.csv("F.Sal.16.csv")

colnames_cleaned <- colnames(faculty_data)

colnames_cleaned <- str_replace_all(
  colnames_cleaned,
  "^Instructional\\.staff\\.on\\.9\\.\\.10\\.\\.11\\.or\\.12\\.month\\.contract\\.(men|women|total)\\.\\.SAL(\\d{4}).*\\.\\.(Professor|Associate\\.professor|Assistant\\.professor)\\.",
  "Number_\\2_\\3_\\1"
)

colnames_cleaned <- str_replace_all(
  colnames_cleaned,
  "^Average\\.salary\\.for\\.instructional\\.staff\\.on\\.9\\.month\\.contract\\.(men|women|total)\\.\\.SAL(\\d{4}).*\\.\\.(Professor|Associate\\.professor|Assistant\\.professor)\\.",
  "Average_\\2_\\3_\\1"
)

colnames(faculty_data) <- colnames_cleaned



long_data <- faculty_data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("Average"), 
               names_to = c("year", "rank", "gender"),
               names_pattern = "Average_(\\d{4})_(.*)_(.*)", 
               values_to = "salary") %>%
  mutate(year = as.integer(year))

long_count <- faculty_data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("Number"), 
               names_to = c("year", "rank", "gender"),
               names_pattern = "Number_(\\d{4})_(.*)_(.*)", 
               values_to = "n") %>%
  mutate(year = as.integer(year))


long_combined <- left_join(long_data, long_count, by = c("year", "rank", "gender"))


filtered_data <- long_combined %>%
  filter(gender != "total")

p_salary <- ggplot(filtered_data, aes(x = year, y = salary, color = gender, group = gender,
                                      text = paste("Year:", year,
                                                   "<br>Salary:", scales::label_dollar()(salary),
                                                   "<br>n:", n))) +
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~rank) +
  labs(title = "Average Salary from 2016-2022", x = "Year", y = "Salary") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("women" = "#993366", "men" = "#5d437c", "total" = "#6fa9b8")) +
  theme_few() +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_dollar())

interactive_salary_plot <- ggplotly(p_salary, tooltip = "text")

interactive_salary_plot






The salary averages for women vs men has women consistently below the average. A limitation of this dataset is that there is no context in terms of seniority, field or department, or productivity. It is hard to say that there is discrimination at play in this scenario, primarily because of the lesser amount of seniority and years of merit and salary increase to boost the average of the gender. Women only recently have been receiving PhDs at the same rate as men, so I anticipate that as faculty retire, the salaries will level out.


Racial Demographics


Code
long_faculty_race <- faculty_curr %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = -instnm,
    names_to = "key",
    values_to = "n"
  )

long_faculty_race <- long_faculty_race %>%
  separate(key, into = c("race", "gender", "year", "rank"), sep = "_", remove = FALSE)

long_faculty_race_clean <- long_faculty_race %>%
  filter(gender != "NA", race != "NA", rank != "Unknown")


long_faculty_race_clean <- long_faculty_race_clean %>%
  filter(!str_detect(key, "Grand"))  # Remove rows with 'Grand'

long_faculty_race_clean <- long_faculty_race_clean %>%
  mutate(rank = case_when(
    str_detect(key, "Professor") ~ "Professor",
    str_detect(key, "Associate") ~ "Associate",
    str_detect(key, "Assistant") ~ "Assistant",
    TRUE ~ rank 
  )) %>%
  separate(key, into = c("race", "gender", "year", "rank"), sep = "_") 



long_faculty_race_clean <- long_faculty_race %>%
  filter(gender == "total") 


stackedrace <- ggplot(long_faculty_race_clean, aes(x =year , y = n, fill = race)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") + 
  facet_wrap(~rank) + 
  labs(title = "Faculty Count by Race and Rank from 2012-2022", 
       x = "Year", 
       y = "Number of Faculty") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("AIAN" = "#006400",
                              "Black" = "#4B0082",
                              "White" = "#003366",
                              "Asian" = "#800080",
                              "Hispanic" = "#800000",
                              "NHPI" = "#2F4F4F", 
                              "Two" = "#008080")) +
  theme_few() + scale_x_discrete(breaks = function(x) x[seq(1, length(x), by = 2)])+ theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))


interactive_plot <- ggplotly(stackedrace)
interactive_plot






Race categorizations changed in the IPEDS system around 2010, so the data collection changed during that year. However, the recent data conveys that higher education continues to be pervasively white. Despite Boston University being founded on the principles of “inclusion, regardless of gender, race, or religion,” having Black and Japanese Law graduates as early as 1877, naming Howard Thurman as the first Black dean in a predominantly white university in 1953, graduating Dr. Martin Luther King Jr with a PhD in 1955, launching the Center for Antiracist Research in 2020, and currently having a black, female president, Dr. Melissa Gilliam, BU’s faculty demographics have evolved minimally and are not reflective of the United States population. The leaky pipeline is clear. The junior faculty are (marginally) more diverse than the tenured faculty.


Conclusions
We see much change at the assistant professor level, which bodes well for the future of higher education. More diverse people are being welcomed into academia, and now the challenge is to foster an inclusive climate in order to retain the exceptional scholars hired at the university.

title: Admissions
text:
College application season is a stressful time for high school seniors. As schools get more selective, transparency in the process helps students from all backgrounds understand what is happening in the admissions landscape!

Rates


Code
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(readr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(stringr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(tidyr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(ggplot2)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(dplyr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(ggthemes)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(hrbrthemes)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(plotly)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(scales)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(janitor)))


df <- read_csv("Adm.Num.01.csv")
df_clean <- df %>%
  clean_names() %>%
  rename(year = x1)
df_long <- df_clean %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(applicants_total, admissions_total, enrolled_total),
               names_to = "Category", values_to = "Total") %>%
  mutate(Category = factor(Category, levels = c("applicants_total", "admissions_total", "enrolled_total"),
                           labels = c("Applicants", "Admissions", "Enrollments")))

p <- ggplot(df_long, aes(x = factor(year), y = Total, fill = Category)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +
  labs(title = "Total Applicants, Admissions, and Enrollments Over Time",
       x = "Year", y = "Total Count", fill = "Category") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Applicants" = "#008B8B",
                              "Admissions" = "#006400",
                              "Enrollments" = "#FFD700")) + 
  theme(legend.position = "top", axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

ggplotly(p)






The evident trend is that the number of applicants is climbing while the admissions and enrollments hover around the same value. We live in a society where prestige and selectivity is more important than educational quality and personal “fit.” Every year, schools get more selective and acceptance rates drop, much to the delight of the institutions who are eager to flaunt their low acceptance rates. Yet, this is because more students are applying to universities, all of whom competing for a small number of spots. Many highly capable students are being rejected, not due to their merit, but due to the large volume of applications. To this end, the college admissions process has become less about working hard and getting good grades, and more about gaming the system in order to stand out among an ocean of other applicants with good grades.


Gender


Code
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(readr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(stringr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(tidyr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(ggplot2)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(dplyr)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(ggthemes)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(hrbrthemes)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(plotly)))
suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(library(scales)))

df <- read_csv("Adm.Num.01.csv")

df_clean <- df %>%
  clean_names() %>%
  rename(year = x1)



df_gender_long <- df_clean %>%
  select(year,
         applicants_men, applicants_women,
         admissions_men, admissions_women,
         enrolled_men, enrolled_women) %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = -year,
    names_to = c("category", "gender"),
    names_sep = "_",
    values_to = "number"
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    category = case_when(
      category == "applicants" ~ "Applicants",
      category == "admissions" ~ "Admissions",
      category == "enrolled"   ~ "Enrollments",
      TRUE ~ category
    ),
    gender = case_when(
      gender == "men" ~ "Men",
      gender == "women" ~ "Women",
      TRUE ~ gender
    ))

df_rates <- df_clean %>%
  transmute(
    year,
    admissions_rate_men   = admissions_men / applicants_men,
    admissions_rate_women = admissions_women / applicants_women,
    yield_rate_men        = enrolled_men / admissions_men,
    yield_rate_women      = enrolled_women / admissions_women
  )
admit_long <- df_rates %>%
  select(year, admissions_rate_men, admissions_rate_women) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = -year, names_to = "group", values_to = "rate") %>%
  mutate(
    Metric = "Admissions Rate",
    Gender = ifelse(group == "admissions_rate_men", "Men", "Women")
  )
yield_long <- df_rates %>%
  select(year, yield_rate_men, yield_rate_women) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = -year, names_to = "group", values_to = "rate") %>%
  mutate(
    Metric = "Yield Rate",
    Gender = ifelse(group == "yield_rate_men", "Men", "Women")
  )
df_long_rates <- bind_rows(admit_long, yield_long)

p <- ggplot(df_long_rates, aes(x = factor(year), y = rate, fill = Gender)) +
geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = position_dodge(width = 0.9))+
  facet_wrap(~Metric) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1), limits = c(0, 1)) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Women" = "#c73e4e", "Men" = "#5d437c")) +
  labs(
    title = "Admissions and Yield Rates by Gender",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Percentage",
    fill = "Gender"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1, size = 10),
    strip.text = element_text(face = "bold")
  )
ggplotly(p)






For a period of time between 2001 and 2017, acceptance rates were always higher for women. In recent years, this has flipped, while the university’s yield predictions have been rather stable. For women, the acceptance rate peaked in 2011 at ~60% and was at its lowest 15% in 2021 (based on this dataset). In just 10 years, the acceptance rate has quartered!


Code
df_admit <- select(df_long, year, applicants_men, applicants_women)

df_admit_long <- df_admit %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(applicants_men, applicants_women),
               names_to = "Gender",
               values_to = "Count")
a <- ggplot(df_admit_long , aes(x = factor(year), y = Count, fill = Gender)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +
  labs(title = "Applicants Over Time by Gender",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Number of Applicants",
       fill = "Gender") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("applicants_men" = "#5d437c", "applicants_women" = "#c73e4e")) +
  theme(legend.position = "top", axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

ggplotly(a)






We can see that the number of women applying to BU is significantly higher than the number of men, with the difference increasing over time. The student body is predominantly female, and the predominantly male faculty body does not represent the students.


Code
df_enroll <- select(df_long, year, enrolled_men, enrolled_women)

df_enroll_long <- df_enroll %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(enrolled_men, enrolled_women),
               names_to = "Gender",
               values_to = "Count")
enroll_stacked <- ggplot(df_enroll_long, aes(x = factor(year), y = Count, fill = Gender)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "stack") +
  labs(title = "Enrollments Over Time by Gender",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Number of Enrollees",
       fill = "Gender") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("enrolled_men" = "#5d437c", "enrolled_women" = "#c73e4e")) +
  theme(legend.position = "top", axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

ggplotly(enroll_stacked)






The highest enrollment in recent years was in 2021, which marked Boston University’s return to in-person learning following the COVID-19 pandemic. This large class is graduating this year, in 2025, and the size of the class has led to tickets being required at commencement for the first time. However, there were more students enrolled in the 2011 class, so it is a bit odd that the university has stressed that the class of 2025 is enormous when in it in line with the class sizes of the 2000s.

title: Conclusion
text: This project seeks to show how Boston University has changed over the past few decades using publicly available data. By visualizing data on demographics, salaries, personnel numbers, and finances—and situating these trends within the context of the university’s history and broader world events—we can begin to understand the patterns that emerge, as well as raise new questions about what the institution’s history may be concealing. Understanding why and how these trends occur helps us better grasp the movements of higher education more broadly. Knowing where BU has been allows us to start imagining where it’s headed, and this project demonstrates the power of data and communication in shaping the future of the university.

title: Implications
text:
As a former student of Boston University and current administrator at Boston University, much of my life has been spent within the BU community. I know the policies like the back of my hand, I can name every HUB requirement, I have a breadth of connections with colleagues across the university, and I spend my days and evenings helping others connect with the institution in the ways I have. I can recite Boston University’s pitch (WORLD-CLASS R1 RESEARCH INSTITUTION) and why it is special, and I can repeat the various accomplishments (FIRST WOMAN PHD! MARTIN LUTHER KING JR!!). However, this project showed me what BU is beyond the narrative. While it is important to know the proud history of the institution you are affiliated with, being able to see long-term trends will specifically help me in various capacities of my job. I can see now that women are not obtaining tenure and can support our faculty in their tenure and promotion cases. I can see the tuition increase and the subsequent rise in financial aid and can communicate that to students. I can perceive the BU community from a bird’s-eye view and bring that knowledge into my everyday interactions.
For a long time, much of the information about BU has been conveyed to me through the grapevine and through anecdotes—a student sharing that their aid package wasn’t enough, a staff member saying that female faculty aren’t being retained, or a graduate student sharing that they feel unsupported and are leaving the program. These are not secrets—they’re available on IPEDS in number form and just need to be organized into graphs in order to pull back the mask on BU.

title: Introduction
text: Using publicly available Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS) records, this project visualizes trends and movement at Boston University over the past few decades. Through statistical visualization, this project examines changes in gender and racial demographics among faculty and students, admissions patterns, financial considerations, completion rates, and degrees categorized by CIP codes, among other factors. By comparing these numerical trends to the university’s history, prominent contemporaneous events, and BU’s self-representation, this project provides a holistic, yet data informed picture of Boston University from around 1980 to the present. The objective of this project is to examine how numerical values are interpreted and explained through trends and events in higher education, and how we can use these trends to begin institutional conversations about where we have come from, where we are now, where we are going, and what we can do to change the university’s trajectory.
